BusinessUnit.title: BusinessUnit
BusinessUnit.description: Represents a business unit within the Shetue Group.

id.description: Unique identifier for the BusinessUnit entity.

name.description: The canonical name of the business unit (e.g., Setu Filling Station).

aliases.description: An array of aliases or alternative names for the business unit.

Metric.title: Metric
Metric.description: Represents a performance metric tracked for a specific business unit.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Metric entity.

name.description: The canonical name of the metric (e.g., daily_sales).

description.description: A detailed description of what the metric measures.

unit.description: The unit of measurement for the metric (e.g., liters, count, percentage).

id.description: Unique identifier for the Dashboard entity.

name.description: The name of the dashboard (e.g., Fuel Dashboard).

description.description: A brief description of the dashboard's purpose.

layout.description: The layout configuration of the dashboard widgets (e.g., grid-auto).

Widget.title: Widget
Widget.description: Represents a single widget on a dashboard, displaying a specific metric.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Widget entity.

visualization.description: The type of visualization used for the widget (e.g., line, bar, kpi).

timeframe.description: The timeframe for the data displayed in the widget (e.g., past_30d, today).

Alert.title: Alert
Alert.description: Represents an alert rule that triggers notifications when specific conditions are met.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Alert entity.

conditionOperator.description: The operator used in the alert condition (e.g., <, >, ==).

conditionValue.description: The value used in the alert condition.

durationMinutes.description: The duration for which the condition must be met before the alert is triggered.

notifyChannels.description: An array of notification channels to use (e.g., telegram, email, sms).

severity.description: The severity level of the alert (e.g., low, medium, high).

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to provide a secure, scalable, and debuggable solution for the ExecuDash application, focusing on authorization independence and clear access patterns.

Authorization Independence:
To avoid hierarchical authorization dependencies, the design denormalizes authorization context where necessary. For example, if access to widgets depends on the dashboard's members, the `members` map is copied into each widget document. This eliminates the need for `get()` calls in security rules, enabling atomic operations and simplifying debugging.

Structural Segregation:
The design segregates data based on access requirements. User-specific data (dashboards) is stored under the `/users/{userId}` path, while business unit data is stored at the root level. This ensures that all documents in a collection share the same security requirements, simplifying the rules.

Access Modeling:
The structure employs consistent access modeling patterns:
- Path-Based Ownership: Dashboards are owned by users, using the `/users/{userId}/dashboards/{dashboardId}` path.
- Membership Map: If collaborative access is needed (not explicitly defined but good practice), this can be implemented in the dashboard or widget level (if necessary).

QAPs (Rules are not Filters):
The structure supports secure `list` operations by ensuring that rules do not act as filters. Data segregation and denormalization (if necessary) allow efficient queries without compromising security.
